page.title: 11LANDSCAPE CUCKFIELD RURAL
page.content: The river Ouse grows from two tiny water falls in the nearby village of Slaugham,into a tidal river reaching the sea at Newhaven.The stream is already several metres wide when it flows under the Staplefield - Cuck- field road at Hamerhill bridge formerly knowan as Gastons bridge. The Garston family was documented in 1296, but the name was corrupted to Gasson by 1823 and is still common locally. Cultivations near the south bank still expose black earth indicating iron working in the past.The river can be reached at several points by public footpaths as it flows through arable fields.In the river Millers Thumb or Bullhead fish can be found,and in its wooded banks live Water Voles. The river is over 3 m. wide as it passes beneath Upper and Lower Pilstye bridg- es towards the Ouse railway viaduct.
